description: From Irish créatúr (“creature”). Doublet of creature. For semantic development, compare creature comfort, and subsequent influence in the early modern era by the Bible:

examples: Now Tim had a sort o' the tipplin' way
With a love of the liquor poor Tim was born
And to help him on with his work each day
He'd a drop of the craythur ev'ry morn.
[...] why, at home, if a craythur hasn't a hat to pull, he'll pull the hair off his head, sooner than not make a bow.
Shut ye'r mouth, do, and go on, ye little ill-reared winkle; [...]
